captions.text:
There's only one thing harder
than keeping stupid things

from happening to people
and that's keeping people

from doing stupid
things to themselves.

You've probably heard
about bath salts.

Not the kind for bathing,
but the kind that's making people

do batcrap-crazy stuff
all over the place,

like climbing up telephone
poles and jumping into traffic,

or killing your neighbor's
goat while wearing lingerie.
Yeah...that actually-

Those are things
that actually happened.
But the important question is why?
And also...why?!
[INTRO]

Bath salts are an amphetamine-like
drug that got their start

in the UK as a club drug—basically
a cheap alternative to ecstasy.

They've only become a
problem in the United States
in the past couple of years,

in 2011, over 6,100 emergencies
involving bath salts were reported

by poison-control centers, up from
303 cases in 2010, the year before.

Suddenly emergency rooms all over
the country have been seeing

people who snorted, smoked,
injected or ate something that

made them act so psychotic that
even large doses of sedatives
couldn't calm them down.

Some of these people could only be
knocked out by general anesthesia.

Symptoms included fevers up to
107 F, along with extreme paranoia,

dangerously high blood
pressure and heart rates,

and blood toxicity
bordering on kidney failure.

These drugs, which have also been
marketed as plant fertilizer,

incense and cleaning products,
contain a group of synthetic

stimulants called
substituted cathinones.

Cathinone is an organic stimulant
found in a plant called khat

that's native to the
Middle East and East Africa
and it's a dangerous and illegal drug.

Most bath salts use one
of two main substitutes:

mephedrone or
methylenedioxypyrovalerone.

Which, because of it being really
long is generally just called MDPV.

As with drugs like cocaine and
meth, these substitutes stimulate

the central nervous system while
messing with one of our most beloved

neurotransmitters, dopamine, the
chemical that our brain squirts out

to reward us when we do
something good for our survival
like eating food or having sex.

The more dopamine our neurons
get, the better we feel.
For a little while, at least.

But in a person's brain, the synthetic
cathinones found in bath salts

combine the effects of both
cocaine and meth at the same time.

On one hand, they block the
reabsorption of excess dopamine

that's floating around among
your neurons, just like coke does.

And on the other hand,
they boost the production
of even more dopamine, like meth does.

Now with a brain drowning in dopamine,
it becomes so overstimulated

that some bath salt highs, or hells,
as it were, can go on for days,
and your brain can't get a break.

And if you've ever even
gone a day without sleeping,
you know how crazy that can make you.

So add that to paranoia,
panic attacks, and mood swings

and you too, might
start stabbing goats.

At this point, the main ingredients
of most bath salts have been banned

in at least 41 states,
but bath-salt cookers,

just like crystal meth cookers,
are trying to get around the law

by concocting different but similar
chemicals that have the same effect.

Basically inventing
new cathinone substitutes.

That means that in
addition to destroying

people's brains, hearts,
and lives, these drug makers

are using the users as human
guinea pigs for a profit.
Fantastic!

So, seriously you guys, I know that
this is not the target audience

for these drugs.
Don't do drugs.

And most especially,
don't do new drugs that

nobody knows what they do,
because you never know

what's gonna make you, like,
go eat your neighbor's dog.

Thanks for watching
this episode of SciShow.
A fascinating but also scary

and unfortunate that we
had to cover this topic.

If you want to keep getting
smarter with us you can go to
youtube.com/scishow and subscribe.

And if you have anything else that
you'd like us to cover or talk about,

or just questions to ask,
we're always on Facebook or Twitter,
or of course, in the comments below.

comments.text:
Mephedrone is actually 4-methylmethcathinone (MCAT) and is much safer than 
methylendixypyrovalerone (MPDV). It hit big in the UK around 2007/2008, 
mostly due to a shortage of both quality ecstasy tablets and crystal 
MDMA There was a massive moral panic and a lot of scare stories but MCAT 
was only directly lined to three deaths, and that was in cases of extremely 
excessive consumption (one person was injecting it). I'm not recommending 
it but mephedrone was not that dangerous compared to the compounds that 
followed it like MPDV and many others. The main problem was the 
addictiveness, especially as it was really cheap and easy to get online 
when it first came out.﻿

comments.text:
+Cody Arnold Fair enough. I must say I am glad that your comment simply was 
a misunderstanding, as your comment was too well-stated to be equating hugs 
and hit-and-runs.
comments.author: Dan Gould

comments.text:
+Dan Gould I started writing a long response but lost it all switching 
pages... Basically, I take my remark on your opinion back. I didn't read 
the full comments. I get what you're saying. My point on stimuli was not 
that they are equal, but that they are all stimuli: they affect you 
somehow, and they all come with possible benefits and possible 
risks/downsides. The conceptual separation between stimulation through 
substance and stimulation through anything else like driving or having 
coffee is arbitrary. Every other action comes with its own set of benefits, 
risks, and cons, but you don't call them poison or especially dangerous.
comments.author: Cody Arnold

comments.text:
+Cody Arnold Your entire argument is based on false analogy logical 
fallacy, and you have the gall to accuse me of logical deficiency.
Okay then.

First, all stimuli is not equal, and to say so is the highest bounds of 
stupidity. Getting hugged and getting hit with a truck both are external 
stimuli. Both touch your body, which then sends signals to your brain. 
Surprisingly, THAT DOES NOT MEAN GETTING HIT WITH A TRUCK AND GETTING 
HUGGED ARE THE SAME!

Second, the definition of drugs are substances that affect the human body. 
However, it takes a remarkably thick person to look through this comment 
chain, and then assume I meant all drugs. I will give you a hint, since 
apparently you are the aforementioned remarkably thick person. I DO NOT 
MEAN MEDICINAL DRUGS, NOR DO I MEAN FOOD/DRINK.

Third, since everything carries some risk, it obviously can't be 
irresponsible to take risks. However, performing actions with high risk is 
irresponsible. For example, chances of dying in a car crash are very low, 
making utilization of cars a responsible decision.
Meanwhile, the chances of dying from ingesting poison are very high, making 
it an irresponsible decision. Risk is always there, but it varies from 
action to action. Obviously.

Fourth, the issue here isn't risk. Anytime you take meth, you aren't 
"risking" danger, you are consuming poison, and immediately damaging your 
health. It isn't risky to do drugs, it is suicidal.

Fifth, the idea that putting poison into your body is bad, is not an 
opinion. It is a medical, irrefutable fact. It is not an opinion that 
copper is conductive, nor that the moon's gravitation causes the tides, nor 
that the boiling point of water is 100 degrees Celsius, it is fact. Learn 
the difference.

Sixth, opinions cannot be cowardly. I sincerely hope that was just a typo, 
but I imagine it isn't, considering you.

Seventh, yours is the most disappointing comment I have come across in 
quite a while, and I would appreciate it if you became educated before you 
comment again.

Eighth, have a wonderful life, and be sure to keep it long by not actively 
poisoning your body. Don't do drugs, kids.
comments.author: Dan Gould

comments.text:
+Cody Arnold
And on a completely unrelated side note, it isn't recommended to do any 
drugs that are "esoteric" in a sense (e.g: Krokodil, DiPT, Benzo Fury, 
etc), at least without some basic research, since those could mess you up.
comments.author: Ryan Sample

comments.text:
+Dan Gould Do you drink coffee? Do you drink alcohol? Tea? Maybe you use 
melatonin for sleep. Surely you've had sugar before. You likely enjoy 
music, and maybe the feeling of taking your socks off, or watching a funny 
movie. Do you do these things responsibly? 

What are all those things? External stimuli that are altering your 
consciousness. "Drugs can't be used responsibly." Really? How does that in 
any way come from logic? What about all the people who take pain meds for 
an injury, smoke weed (even every day), drink coffee in the morning, get 
drunk on Fridays, and alter their consciousness in general who DON'T 
negatively affect their lives or others at all? 

Maybe at this point you'd argue, "You never know what could happen if you 
take something. Taking that risk is always irresponsible." There are many 
direct examples that prove you wrong, but I'll make it more obvious just 
for you.

You probably drive a car. You are risking an accident every time, and 
there's even a chance of ending others' lives. HOWEVER, you probably have a 
driver's license with experience and skill and knowledge of driving. You 
have drastically reduced your risk of death/injury/pull-over because you 
want to avoid an accident, so you became a responsible driver. Same thing 
with psychoactives. There are some objectively dangerous drugs that are 
unpredictable in nature like bath-salts and new chems, but not all. That's 
why you are wrong. Your opinion is wrong and cowardly, and you have no 
valid argument.
comments.author: Cody Arnold

comments.author: Kieren Pearson

comments.text:
+Brandon Lester Shulgin spent most of his later life at the Farm in 
Lafayette, California. On April 8, 2008, at the age of 82, he underwent 
surgery to replace a defective aortic valve.[14] On November 16, 2010, he 
suffered a stroke, from which he largely recovered.[15] Also at the close 
of 2010, a skin-grafting surgery saved his left foot from being amputated. 
Unfortunately, around this time, Shulgin began showing early signs of 
dementia, mostly severe loss of short-term memory. With progression of the 
dementia since 2010, his wife Ann Shulgin had been trying to sell part of 
their property to raise more money to cover care costs.[16]

On April 17, 2014, Ann Shulgin reported on Facebook that her husband had 
developed liver cancer, and in a May 31 update on Facebook she said that, 
although appearing frail, he seemed to be experiencing his last moments in 
peace and without pain.[17] On June 2, 2014, Shulgin died at home in bed 
surrounded by friends and family, at the age of 88.[18]

comments.text:
ANYTHING can kill you if you ingest enough (water, table salt, aspirin, 
etc) and anything enjoyable can be habit-forming, possibly leading to 
over-consumption. If you do no research about doses and their typical 
effects, and take a lot of something you've never tried... it's not your 
coach-driver's fault where you end up. Nor is it the devil's fault. As it 
turns out, neither of them are likely to actually exist... and it's not 
anyone's fault but yours. Poundsign-TheTruthHurts 凸(>皿<)凸

comments.author: nick coleman

comments.text:
Dude your crazy.

To do salts every single day is to put your body at major risk.

Atleast drugs like cocain, lsd, heroin and other known drugs all have been 
studied for their long term effects.
Bath salts just came out and there is no way of knowing what it can do to 
your health in the long run.
Take ketamine for example, when it first came out, people where doing it 
every day for long periods of time, and just in the last decade they find 
out its adverse effects on the bladder. Big time users and addicts have 
ended up with parts of their bladder to even the whole thing having to be 
extesivley operated on under surgery for the damage ketamine has caused.

Im in no way against drugs, but what i sm against is the irresponsible ways 
people use them, eventually becoming the statistics the media talks about. 
Be safe.

From one drug addict to another

Like I know a lot of countries in Europe let their kids have SIPS of 
alcohol at very young ages. And honestly for the most part it teaches 
moderation, you don't suddenly turn 21 and want to drink your weight in 
beer. I think lots of older cultures also have such a relationship with 
tobacco/other smoked things. (Not native american so not going into that 
one.) Culture can teach us to deal with these things responsibly. However 
the child of an addict might disagree with me, and that's ok and completely 
understandable.﻿

comments.text:
I know that...  I asked you to list a toxin in them and you said DNA. 
What.  Ok...  jokes aside are you trolling or not ? There's nothing listed 
as toxic inside the commonly used species of psilocybin mushrooms. They are 
listed as PSYCHOACTIVE not toxic. You need to learn the difference. There 
is no other toxic compound listed in them. There is nothing else in them 
that does anything at all, psychoactive or otherwise. No other actives. It 
really is that simple.  Your started by saying other chemicals in them are 
poisonous at lower concentrations, yet you can't list a single one, because 
there are none. Stop making shit up.
comments.author: CustardBastard

comments.text:
+CustardBastard saying that the only "active" compound in shrooms is 
psilocybin is like saying tartrazine has no adverse health effects because 
it's only included for the purpose of dying food.... like purpose has any 
bearing at all on the chemical properties of a compound.

But no, shrooms don't contain lysergic acid diethelide.... unless you soak 
them first.
comments.author: Isaac Karjala

comments.text: No it's lysergic acid diethTROLLide
comments.author: CustardBastard

comments.text: +CustardBastard deoxyribose nucleic acid.
comments.author: Isaac Karjala

comments.text:
+Isaac Karjala
 And what other chemicals are those ? The only active compound in 
psychoactive psilocybin mushrooms is psilocybin and psilocin which the 
former becomes when ingested.
comments.author: CustardBastard

comments.text:
+CustardBastard I don't get this. The principal psychoactive compound in 
shrooms is not poisonous when consumed at sane levels.... But other 
chemicals in shrooms are poisonous at much lower concentrations.... Why is 
one chemical considered an "active ingredient", but not the other? All the 
chemicals are active, even if they are not contributing to the desired 
effect.
comments.author: Isaac Karjala

comments.text: +DrHillbillyShow why
comments.author: m2350

comments.text:
You mean drugs designed for treating psychosis do just the opposite? 
Indeed, think there is a lot of truth to that, which is why we must stop 
outright banning the alternatives. The amount of people addicted to 
antidepressants and anti-psychotics, especially in America, is an epidemic. 
That's why we have to stop banning the safer alternatives and do some 
proper research.
comments.author: CustardBastard

comments.text:
+Madara Uchiha
Drug ABUSE is for the weak, not the drugs themselves, but people get very 
angry and upset about this topic because there has been massive amounts of 
propaganda since the 60's as the world has adopted the American model. This 
is exactly the kind of attitude that bans, for example, mushrooms, of which 
the active compound has never caused a single death or illness, and has 
thousands of years of history of use. Even in clinical trials has proven to 
treat depression and had longer lasting positive effects and is less 
harmful than prescription drugs. And so back to my point, these novel 
psychoactive substances are created to fill the gap. No culture has ever 
came into contact with these new compounds which come onto the market to 
replace those substances which have been banned in a knee-jerk reaction. 
And it is those substances which kill. And here come the knee jerks and 
personal insults, I guess I better brace myself... But hey, don't just take 
my word for it, google awaits!
comments.author: CustardBastard

comments.author: CustardBastard

comments.text:
How about this *perfectly legal* thing that will NEVER be banned....
Put 1 quart of water in a pot and turn the heat to *medium* - NOT full 
boil. 
When it starts to steam pour in 1 cup of salt, regular salt not special 
'gourmet' sea salt & stir till dissolved. When it's dissolved stir in 1/4 
cup of baking soda, not powder. Any brand will work does not need to be Arm 
& Hammer. THEN when that's dissolved, cover and let it cool. When it's 
cooled to room temp drink a 14-16 oz glass but very quickly - it will be 
salty and hard to swallow so don't sip. You will get high as a satellite 
for about 8-10 minutes....try it.

to let me hit it for the free all I can say is bye-bye brain cells. :3

comments.author: edward corbett

comments.text:
+Claude Jester Actually some THC analogues are not as dangerous as people 
make them out to be, the problem is that many of them are a lot more potent 
than THC (some reports saying that certain RC's are x100 more psychoactive 
than normal THC). People have this strange idea that chemicals produced 
synthetically are bad, while this may be true in certain cases, there are 
definite exceptions. Take something like LSD or its many analogues (LSZ, 
PRO-LAD, LA-LAD) or something like MDMAT which is a non nuerotoxic 
substance. That's why it is so important to research chemicals you put into 
your body. It's surprising how many people do not even care what they are 
taking or even bother to test substances they ingest.
